title: Spalding Walks - Near and Around

images.caption: River Welland, Spalding. The river has been canalized in the fens and runs in straight embanked stretches.

images.title: Stephen McKay / River Welland, Spalding
images.caption: River Welland, Spalding. Showing the terminus of the Spalding Water Taxi and the Lincolnshire Poacher pub.

images.title: Graham Horn / River Glen
images.caption:
River Glen at Willow Tree Fen. Although a remote area, there are a number of features to describe here. The River Glen, running south to north, is channelled to provide drainage and flood protection. The flood banks are further apart than normal here though. Although mainly still arable farming, these are the first cows we have seen since leaving Boston on the Macmillan Way 24 miles earlier.
The brick pillars in the middle distance are the remains of a bridge over the river carrying the Bourne to Spalding railway, closed in 1959.
Beyond are two poles carrying owl nesting boxes, provided by the Hawk and Owl Trust. Most are inhabited by anything other than owls these days though.

description: This Lincolnshire based market town has some nice waterside walking trails to try through the attractive countryside of the Fens. This circular walk from the town visits the Willow Tree Fen Nature Reserve, the River Glen and the neighbouring village of Pinchbeck. The walk starts on Sharp's Bridge to the north of the town. Here you can pick up a waterside trail heading south west along Vernatt's Drain to the Nature Reserve. Here you pick up the Macmillan Way and follow it north along the River Glen to Pinchbeck. Head south through the town and it will bring you out near Sharp's Bridge.
